Heidi was smiling broadly. "I love it so much. I wasn't expecting to love it, but I just feel blissful. Madaline?"

She walked over to where Madaline, who stood up heavily. "I'm so sorry for being negative about your weight in the past. I understand now why you campaign for this to be the new norm." She drew Madaline into a tight hug and their bellies squished together. "I love you."

She pulled away and took Madaline's place on the couch next to Ted. Madaline herself sat down and the three of them took up the whole of the couch's space, their thighs touching.

"And Ted." Ted looked up at her. "In the past I was worried about your weight. Now I can say you look cute at any weight, but especially with that cute little belly." She patted it.

"Thank you Heidi, that means a lot."

Madaline piped up. "We can't just sit here. We need to do something to celebrate."

141.content:
Performing in school plays is no easy feat; especially when you're consistently the main character. And when you're Director and Producer procure rights to "Into The Woods" and feel the need to keep every song and every scene for integrity, being The Baker may not be the most stress-relieving role. At least Deavon was also cast, and as Jack no less! Too bad they weren't love interests.

After another exhausting day of practice, and several compliments aimed at Justin, everyone begins packing up,ready to leave. Despite the countless compliments he's received, Justin can't help but focus on the couple negative remarks he's gotten. Remarks he's never gotten after his first main role. "Your pitch is too high, your face isn't convincing, etc." Rushing out of the school's theater Justin heads to his car, a blessing and a status of how cool he was. Getting in his car, Justin breathes in and out for several seconds, tired from practicing all day. Justin checks his watch, it's 6:37 PM, his parents are at work and haven't made food, and he's still got homework and classes to study for. Thinking, Justin, sighs before deciding to get fast food, one day can't hurt he reminds himself. Cheat days are natural.

Sadly for Justin, the long hours of practicing don't relent, and the actual play won't be performed until two months from now.
